prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: BR 0401-1711
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: High sensitivity observations of the [CII]158 micron line and FIR continuum in the z=4.228 quasar host BR 0401-1711.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect to detect a broad component of the [CII] line superimposed onto the narrow core, which may be the signature of high velocity gas in outflow (or inflow). Based on our previous results on J1148 (Cicone et al. 2015), although most of the [CII] luminosity should arise from gas with velocity within +-500 km/s, in the presence of powerful QSO feedback we may detect high velocity [CII] emission at v up to +-1000 km/s from the systemic. For this reason, since at these frequencies the maximum bandwidth available within one spectral window is ~1500 km/s, we designed the spectral setup as follows. To cover the full spectral extent of the [CII] line, we placed two spectral windows at a distance of 1.8 GHz, in order to have a safe overlap of 37.5 MHz of the central "full sensitivity" part (given by the central 1.875 GHz of each spw). We note that some overlap between the spectral windows is essential, because it is possible that the spectral windows will slighly move apart during the observations (because of the Doppler correction required to remove the effects of the Earth rotation). Using this setup, we can achieve a total bandwidth of 3.675 GHz, centered on the [CII] line, corresponding to ~3000 km/s. Since the line should be quite broad (1000 km/s), we applied a spectral averaging of a factor of 8 to lower the data rate, providing a spectral resolution of 3 km/s. In the other available sideband, we placed two adjacent spectral windows that will allow us to detect and map the FIR continuum, by avoiding possible contamination from the broad [CII] line.

Based on our results on J1148 (Fig. 1 in the science case, Cicone et al. 2015), high-z quasars may be surrounded by "[CII] halos" with structures extending up to r~30 kpc from the QSO. Since our goal is to recover such extended [CII] emission, we request these observations to be carried out with the most compact configuration of the ALMA 12m array, which, for this source corresponds to a LAS~7'' (~50 kpc at the redshift of BR 0401-1711) and to an angular resolution of 0.95". Our priority is to detect faint and extended [CII] emission, therefore we are not interested in an higher angular resolution, which would require larger integration times to reach a similar sensitivity per beam.

For BR 0401-1711 we have estimated a total bolometric luminosity of 5 x 10^47 erg/s (Fontanot, priv. comm.). From L_Bol, by adopting L_Bol = 1.15*L_IR (Sturm et al. 2011), we infer the total IR luminosity. We conservatively assume that 50% of L_IR is due to star formation. This value is based on the fraction of FIR emission that, in the z=6.4 quasar J1148 (Cicone et al. 2015), is extended and hence certainly not due to the AGN. We therefore estimate a SFR of ~5700 M_sun/yr by using the relation between L_IR and SFR provided by Sturm et al. (2011). We adopt the SFR-L_[CII] relationship of Sargsyan et al. (2014) to estimate the expected total integrated flux of [CII], I_[CII], and from this, by assuming delta_v = 1000 km/s (to account for the possible presence of broad wings), we obtain a peak [CII] flux density of S_peak = 98 mJy. By assuming that the [CII] emission is distributed over a diameter of 8" (> LAS, but for this source the maximum LAS achievable without ACA is only 7", nevertheless the source could be more extended and we take this into account in the sensitivity estimate), we obtain a peak flux density per synthesised beam of 1.4 mJy/beam, and in order to achieve a S/N=5 we request a sensitivity of 0.28 mJy/beam in channels of 200 km/s. The choice of the bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation (200 km/s) is appropriate for the broad [CII] spectral profiles that we expect to observe. We note that the requested sensitivity will also allow us to detect a FIR continuum of 3 mJy (i.e. a conservative estimate based on previous observations of high-z quasars) at high significance.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SDSS J1401+0244
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: High sensitivity observations of the [CII]158 micron emission line and FIR continuum in the z=4.41359 quasar host SDSS J1401+0244.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect to detect a broad component of the [CII] line superimposed onto the narrow core, which may be the signature of high velocity gas in outflow (or inflow). Based on our previous results on J1148 (Cicone et al. 2015), although most of the [CII] luminosity should arise from gas with velocity within +-500 km/s, in the presence of powerful QSO feedback we may detect high velocity [CII] emission at v up to +-1000 km/s from the systemic. For this reason, since at these frequencies the maximum bandwidth available within one spectral window is ~1600 km/s, we designed the spectral setup as follows. To cover the full spectral extent of the [CII] line, we placed two spectral windows at a distance of 1.8 GHz, in order to have a safe overlap of 37.5 MHz of the central "full sensitivity" part (given by the central 1.875 GHz). We note that some overlap between the spectral windows is essential, because it is possible that the spectral windows will slighly move apart during the observations (because of the Doppler correction required to remove the effects of the Earth rotation). Using this setup, we can achieve a total bandwidth of 3.675 GHz, centered on the [CII] line, corresponding to ~3100 km/s. Since the line is quite broad, we applied a spectral averaging of a factor of 8 to lower the data rate, providing a spectral resolution of 3 km/s. In the other available sideband, we placed two adjacent spectral windows that will allow us to detect and map the FIR continuum, by avoiding possible contamination from the broad [CII] line.

Based on our results on J1148 (Fig. 1 in the science case, Cicone et al. 2015), high-z quasars may be surrounded by "[CII] halos" with structures extending up to r~30 kpc from the QSO. Therefore, since our goal is to recover such extended [CII] emission, we request these observations to be carried out with the most compact configuration of the ALMA 12m array, which provides for this source an angular resolution of ~1.0" and is sensitive to LAS~8" (~55 kpc at the redshift of SDSS J1401+0244). Our priority is to detect faint and extended [CII] emission, therefore we are not interested in an higher angular resolution, which would require larger integration times to reach a similar sensitivity per beam.

For SDSS J1401+0244 we have estimated a total bolometric luminosity of 2 x 10^47 erg/s (Fontanot, priv. comm.). From L_Bol, by adopting L_Bol = 1.15*L_IR (Sturm et al. 2011), we infer the total IR luminosity. We conservatively assume that 50% of L_IR is due to star formation. This value is based on the fraction of FIR emission that, in the z=6.4 quasar J1148 (Cicone et al. 2015), is extended and hence certainly not due to the AGN. We therefore estimate a SFR of ~2400 M_sun/yr by using the relation between L_IR and SFR provided by Sturm et al. (2011). We adopt the SFR-L_[CII] relationship of Sargsyan et al. (2014) to estimate the expected total integrated flux of [CII], I_[CII], and from this, by assuming delta_v = 1000 km/s (to account for the possible presence of broad wings), we obtain a peak [CII] flux density of S_peak = 39 mJy. By assuming that the [CII] emission is distributed over a diameter of 8" (LAS), we obtain a peak flux density per synthesised beam of 0.6 mJy/beam, and in order to achieve a S/N=5 we request a sensitivity of 0.12 mJy/beam in channels of 200 km/s. The choice of the bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation (200 km/s) is appropriate for the broad [CII] spectral profiles that we expect to observe. We note that the requested sensitivity will also allow us to detect a FIR continuum of 3 mJy (i.e. a conservative estimate based on previous observations of high-z quasars) at high significance.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: BRI 0952-0115
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: High sensitivity observations of the [CII]158 micron emission line and FIR continuum in the z=4.4337 quasar host BRI 0952-0115.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We expect to detect a broad component of the [CII] line superimposed onto the narrow core, which may be the signature of high velocity gas in outflow (or inflow). Based on our previous results on J1148 (Cicone et al. 2015) and on the ALMA SV [CII] spectrum of BRI 0952-0115 (Fig. 3 of science case), although most of the [CII] luminosity should arise from gas with velocity within +-500 km/s, in the presence of powerful QSO feedback we may detect high velocity [CII] emission at v up to +-1000 km/s from the systemic. For this reason, since at these frequencies the maximum bandwidth available within one spectral window is ~1600 km/s, we designed the spectral setup as follows. To cover the full spectral extent of the [CII] line, we placed two spectral windows at a distance of 1.8 GHz, in order to have a safe overlap of 37.5 MHz of the central "full sensitivity" part (given by the central 1.875 GHz of each spw). We note that some overlap between the spectral windows is essential, because it is possible that the spectral windows will slighly move apart during the observations (because of the Doppler correction required to remove the effects of the Earth rotation). Using this setup, we can achieve a total bandwidth of 3.675 GHz, centered on the [CII] line, corresponding to ~3200 km/s. Since the line is quite broad, we applied a spectral averaging of a factor of 8 to lower the data rate, providing a spectral resolution of 3 km/s. In the other available sideband, we placed two adjacent spectral windows that will allow us to detect and map the FIR continuum, by avoiding possible contamination from the broad [CII] line.

Based on our results on J1148 (Fig. 1 in the science case, Cicone et al. 2015), high-z quasars may be surrounded by "[CII] halos" with structures extending up to r~30 kpc from the QSO. Therefore, since our goal is to recover such extended [CII] emission, we request these observations to be carried out with the most compact configuration of the ALMA 12m array, which, at these frequencies and for this source, provides a maximum LAS of 7.8" (53 kpc at the redshift of the source) and an angular resolution of 1". Our priority is to detect faint and extended [CII] emission, therefore we are not interested in an higher angular resolution, which would require larger integration times to reach a similar sensitivity per beam.

From previous single-dish (APEX) observations of BRI 0952-0115 (Maiolino et al. 2009) we know that the (total) peak flux density of the [CII] emission line is 150 mJy. If assuming that the [CII] source has an angular size of 8", our peak flux density needs to be scaled down by a factor of 64, resulting in a flux density per synthesised beam of 2.3 mJy/beam. We therefore require a sensitivity of 0.46 mJy/beam (corresponding to a SNR=5) in channels of 200 km/s. The choice of the bandwidth used for the sensitivity calculation (200 km/s) is appropriate for a broad spectral [CII] profile (Figure 3 of the science case). We note that the requested sensitivity will allow us to detect at high significance the FIR continuum emission, whose flux density at these frequencies is expected to be 11 mJy/beam (Gallerani et al. 2012).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to obtain high sensitivity maps of the [CII]158 micron emission line and FIR continuum in correspondence of three z>4 quasars showing evidence for associated absorbers in their UV spectra, suggesting the presence of an extended gaseous halo as well as of outflowing and/or inflowing gas. Our goal is to image the "[CII] halo" of distant quasars, and investigate large-scale (tens of kpc) filamentary structures tracing a combination of outflows, dynamically quiescent gas and gas accreting onto the halo. The proposed observations are extremely relevant for understanding the QSO feedback and feeding mechanisms in action in the early Universe and responsible for shaping the evolution of massive galaxies and of their super massive black holes.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Classe di Scienze, Pisa, Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa
